Award.AwardTitle: RAPID Proposal: Constraining kinematics of the Whillans/Mercer Ice Stream Confluence
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Siple Coast in West Antarctica has undergone significant glacier changes over the last millenium. Several ice streams--rapidly moving streams of ice bordered by slow-moving ice--exist in this region that feeds into the Ross Ice Shelf. A long-term slowdown of Whillans Ice Stream appears to be occurring, and this is affecting the zone between the Whillans and Mercer Ice Streams. However, the consistency of this slowdown and resulting changes to the shear margin between the two ice streams are unknown. The goal of this project is to quantify the observed changes over the past decade and understand the dynamic processes that cause them. A collateral benefit of and driver for this as a RAPID project is to test a method for assessing where crevassing will develop in this zone of steep velocity gradients. Such a method may benefit not only near-term field-project planning in the 2018-19 field season, but also planning for future fieldwork and traverses.

The team will use remote sensing feature-tracking techniques to determine transient velocity patterns and shifts in the shear-zone location over the last 10-plus years. This velocity time series will be incorporated into a large-scale ice-sheet model to estimate ice-sheet susceptibility to changing boundary conditions over the next century based on likely regional ice-flux scenarios. This approach is an extension of recent work conducted by the team that shows promise for predicting areas of changing high strain rates indicative of an active glacier shear margin. The ultimate objectives are to characterize the flow field of merging ice streams over time and investigate lateral boundary migration. This will provide a better understanding of shear-margin control on ice-shelf and up-glacier stability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
West Antarctica has experienced significant mass loss along its coastline in recent decades.  This is driven, in large part, by warm ocean waters causing ice shelf thinning and retreat through melt.  Ice shelf mass loss sets off a chain reaction in the form of retreating grounding lines, reduced resistance to ice flow at the bed and margins, and ultimately, dynamic thinning of grounded glaciers through increased glacier velocities.  This process has the potential for causing significant glacier loss in West Antarctica over future decades.  The Siple Coast is one such region which has undergone significant glacier changes over the last ~1000 years, although in a complex manner.  A long-term slowdown of Whillans Ice Stream appears to be occurring, which influences the shear margin dividing Whillans and Mercer Ice Streams. However, the consistency of this slowdown and resulting changes to the shear margin (which acts as a principle resistance to ice flow) are unknown. Our goal was to quantify velocity changes through recent instrumental and satellite records acquired over the region and determine the dynamic processes causing observed changes in this sector of West Antarctica. Shear zone stability represents a potentially critical control on mass balance of ice sheets, especially in regions of fast ice flow where basal shear stress is minimal. This proposal is therefore focused on understanding the spatial and temporal change of ice flow kinematics, shear margin structure, and shear margin location between Whillans and Mercer Ice Streams. We assessed changes in the velocity field and shear margin from 1997 through 2016 using available remote sensing data and developed a finite element numerical  model of ice flow to investigate the potential for ice boundaries downstream of the study area to influence Whillans and Mercer Glacier stability. This proposal was placed within the RAPID proposal category because a field program operating within this sector of Antarctica was in immediate need of ice flow velocity and englacial structure information to safely conduct their research. Our research provided valuable information to assure the safety of their research team and established new methods and frameworks for observing transient glacier velocities and deformation fields in other glacier systems.

Our analysis allows us to determine the deceleration (slow-down) rate of Whillans Ice Stream over the past two decades. For this region, our results suggest that these time dependent effects are related to a change in basal shear stress. While we have not determined the direct cause of change in basal shear stress (i.e. thermomechanical or hydrologic forcing) we have explored the long term effects of changes at the glacier bed through modeling.  Our model results predict a shift in shear margin location if increased friction at the ice-bed interface continue to occur. Through our kinematic analysis, we were also able to identify the magnitude of deceleration of the WIS through both space and time and have provided one of the most spatially expansive records of variable slowdown in the region, to date.  In addition to providing scientific evidence of basal shear stress changes impacting glacier velocities from a science perspective, methods developed in this project also impact future logistical operations supporting science in Antarctica and Greenland.  Prior to major field research campaigns on both ice sheets, significant effort is focused on assessing whether field study sites and access routes are safe.  This includes an assessment of remote sensing data prior to field deployments and the collection of in-situ ground-penetrating radar data which is commonly used to detect sub-surface crevasses. Through this project, we have developed a more extensive framework of remote sensing, geophysical, and numerical modeling methods than previously available, to assess 1) the presence of dynamic changes occurring within or in route to study sites, and 2) the potential for hazardous conditions within or in route to study sites based on both observed and modeled changes in glaciological conditions.  Ultimately, this methodological framework will help with risk management of field science activities in both Antarctica and Greenland.
